questions.question: Which of the following best describes a Use Case Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. Graphical representation of system functionality
questions.option_b: B. Captures non-functional requirements
questions.option_c: C. Shows interaction between system and external entities
questions.option_d: D. Used only in coding phase
questions.explanation: A Use Case Diagram graphically represents system functionality and interactions between the system and external actors.

questions.question: What are the four basic components of a Use Case Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. System
questions.option_b: B. Actors
questions.option_c: C. Use Cases
questions.explanation: A Use Case Diagram consists of the system boundary, actors, use cases, and the relationships between them.

questions.question: Which statement correctly defines a System Boundary?
questions.option_a: A. Separates system from external environment
questions.option_b: B. Includes only external users
questions.option_c: C. Defines hardware configuration
questions.option_d: D. Represents the scope of the system
questions.explanation: The system boundary distinguishes what is inside the system (use cases) from what lies outside (actors).

questions.question: What do Actors represent in Use Case Diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. Roles interacting with the system
questions.option_b: B. External hardware or systems
questions.option_c: C. Developers of the system
questions.option_d: D. Human users or other systems
questions.explanation: Actors represent roles such as users or external systems that interact with the system being modeled.

questions.question: Which are valid examples of actors in a Hotel Management System?
questions.option_a: A. Guest
questions.option_b: B. Receptionist
questions.option_c: C. Manager
questions.explanation: Guests, receptionists, managers, and housekeeping staff are all roles that interact with the hotel system as actors.

questions.question: What does an Association relationship indicate in Use Case Diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. Actor participates in a use case
questions.option_b: B. One actor inherits behavior from another
questions.option_c: C. One use case includes another
questions.option_d: D. Communication link between actor and use case
questions.explanation: An association shows the communication link between an actor and a use case in UML.

questions.question: What is true about Actor Generalization?
questions.option_a: A. A child actor inherits parent behavior
questions.option_b: B. Child actor can add or override parent behavior
questions.option_c: C. It defines associations between actors
questions.option_d: D. Used to represent multiple similar roles
questions.explanation: Actor generalization allows a child actor to inherit all the interactions of its parent actor.

questions.question: Which of the following are true for Include relationships?
questions.option_a: A. Common behavior is reused across use cases
questions.option_b: B. Included use case cannot exist independently
questions.option_c: C. Include adds optional behavior
questions.explanation: Include relationships capture reusable functionality that can be invoked by multiple use cases.

questions.question: Which of the following describe Extend relationships?
questions.option_a: A. Optional behavior added to base use case
questions.option_b: B. Extension occurs under certain conditions
questions.option_c: C. The base use case cannot stand alone
questions.explanation: Extend relationships add optional or conditional behavior that extends a base use case when certain conditions are met.

questions.question: Which statement is true about Use Case Generalization?
questions.option_a: A. Child use case inherits parent behavior
questions.option_b: B. Parent defines common functionality
questions.option_c: C. Used when multiple use cases share a base logic
questions.explanation: In use case generalization, a child use case inherits and specializes the behavior of a parent use case.

questions.question: Which statements correctly describe a Use Case Scenario?
questions.option_a: A. Describes sequence of interactions for a use case instance
questions.option_b: B. Includes main and alternate flows
questions.option_c: C. Defines specific event flow between actors and system
questions.explanation: A use case scenario narratively describes the step-by-step interaction sequence for one instance of a use case.

questions.question: What information is part of a Use Case Template?
questions.option_a: A. Use case ID and name
questions.option_b: B. Goal in context
questions.option_c: C. Pre-conditions
questions.explanation: A typical use case template includes an ID, name, goal, preconditions, and involved actors.

questions.question: What are the common sections of a Use Case Specification?
questions.option_a: A. Summary
questions.option_b: B. Preconditions
questions.option_c: C. Main scenario steps
questions.explanation: Use case specifications often include summary, preconditions, main and alternate flows, and postconditions.

questions.question: Which of the following describe a Main Scenario flow?
questions.option_a: A. Steps executed when everything goes right
questions.option_b: B. Describes success path
questions.option_c: C. Includes errors and exceptions
questions.explanation: A main scenario flow represents the primary success path of interaction between actor and system.

questions.question: Which are true about Extensions in a Use Case Scenario?
questions.option_a: A. Describe alternative flows
questions.option_b: B. Represent exceptional conditions
questions.option_c: C. Triggered by external or internal conditions
questions.explanation: Extensions define alternative or exceptional flows that occur under specific conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following are benefits of using Use Case Diagrams in Requirements Engineering?
questions.option_a: A. Easy communication with stakeholders
questions.option_b: B. Represents what the system will do
questions.option_c: C. Avoids technical jargon
questions.explanation: Use case diagrams facilitate communication between stakeholders by visually capturing system functionality.

questions.question: Which is a correct example of an Include relationship?
questions.option_a: A. Validate user in Withdraw Money use case
questions.option_b: B. Check account balance in Transfer Funds
questions.option_c: C. Print receipt in Deposit Money
questions.option_d: D. User registration in Attend Workshop
questions.explanation: ‘Validate user’ is a common functionality reused by multiple banking use cases, representing an include relationship.

questions.question: Which is an example of an Extend relationship?
questions.option_a: A. Perform visa check if student is foreign
questions.option_b: B. Suggest add item if not found in library search
questions.option_c: C. Validate member when borrowing book
questions.explanation: Optional behavior such as performing a visa check applies only under specific conditions, representing an extend relationship.

questions.question: Which of the following are examples of Use Case Generalization?
questions.option_a: A. Make Payment → Pay via PayPal
questions.option_b: B. Make Payment → Pay via Credit Card
questions.option_c: C. Make Payment → Pay via EFT
questions.explanation: Different payment methods inherit the base functionality of the 'Make Payment' use case, indicating generalization.

questions.question: Which questions help identify use cases for an actor?
questions.option_a: A. What tasks does the actor perform?
questions.option_b: B. Does the actor modify data in the system?
questions.option_c: C. What functions can the actor access?
questions.option_d: D. What UI layout is used?
questions.explanation: To identify use cases, analysts focus on the tasks and goals the actor performs within the system context.
